Award.AbstractNarration:
The vision of creating fully controlled spatial and temporal quantum mechanical electron waves will be realized in the near future. Such coherent electron control offers exciting possibilities for the development of new technologies and the exploration of new physics. The challenge to combine very small (nanometer scale) parts with ultrafast (femto- and atto-second) lasers to control electrons is going to be addressed by the work funded through this grant. The largest enclosed area electron interferometer ever will be built, and electron switches directing signals at extreme rates of about a million GigaHertz will be explored.


The impact of having a largest electron interferometer (that still fits in a car) is that new frequency ranges and sensitivities of electromagnetic fields can be tested. The use of a simple low frequency magnetometer is explored together with Honeywell and these devices are applicable for hunting submarines and locating mines. Higher frequencies are used for detecting electromagnetic communications. On the scientific side, the interferometer will be used to help understand one of the largest puzzles of the century, which is the transition between classical and quantum physics. The impact of having ultrafast electron switches is that this may enable a new generation of devices, such as the fastest microscopes, oscilloscopes and signal processors. The educational impact is that training for graduate students will be provided in an area of national need, while previous outreach has already reached an estimated 100,000 high school students. This grant will allow a continuation of these efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit.

Classical Mechanics is the theory that made it possible to get satellites into orbit, design modern bridges and have many other useful devices. Classical Mechanics works because it can predict what will happen when you start at a certain place and time. Quantum Mechanics gave us the laser, the global positioning system, LED screens and so forth. Nevertheless Quantum Mechanics suffers from the Quantum Measurement Problem. Quantum Mechanics does not give us the complete rules how to predict what is going to happen. In Quantum Mechanics there are actually two rules, one that states how something changes smoothly and one that states how things change abruptly when we measure things. But we have no rules for how to choose between them. Scientist and engineers who use Quantum Mechanics know from experience what to do in a lot of situations, but the rules are incomplete. That is the Quantum Measurement Problem. The solution to the problem has eluded us for almost a century, may change our thinking dramatically and lead to a new major theory.  

The best but incomplete answer is called decoherence theory. This theory can be tested by making things that fall in between the smooth and abrupt. One electron passing by a metal wall is such a thing. The metal wall as a whole pushes smoothly on the electron, while the individual particles in the wall cause abrupt changes. With the funding from NSF we have created a device which with we can now see this change and control this change, by changing the distance of the electron to the wall and thus get a view at the Quantum Measurement Problem.

In our laboratory there are two consequences of pursuing the Quantum Measurement Problem. The first is that we need to understand and explain the basics of quantum mechanics as well as possible. To help this we completely realized the thought experiment of Nobel laureate Richard Feynman on the “electron double slit” for the first time. The “double slit” idea is covered in almost all quantum mechanics text books and its careful explanation is thus important for education. The second is if we can control the abrupt changes, we can build new and hopefully the best performing electron interferometers.

Broader Impacts.

On the educational front, our “double slit” work has been continuously on the “most read” list of the open access journal New Journal of Physics since its publication in 2013, and the accompanying educational movie has been used by more than 100,000 high school students. Pushing the limits to understand the Quantum Measurement Problem drives technology. It is our hope that we can make the world’s largest electron interferometer. These are devices that can measure very small electromagnetic fields. Applications of magnetometers include finding submerged submarines, thus exploring a fundamental issue can also lead to a new technology.

Additionally, the broader impact of our work funded by NSF is Human Resources Development. Since our laboratory first received NSF funding in 2000, we have provided training for four postdoctoral associates, 12 graduate students, and more than 20 undergraduate students. Our current group funded by the current grant includes three graduate students and two undergraduate students. After their training, postdoctoral researcher Kayvan Aflatooni became an assistant professor at Fort Hays State University in Kansas; postdoctoral associate Jin Wang became an assistant professor at the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga; and postdoctoral researcher Pavel Lougovski took a staff position at Argonne National Laboratory. All nine graduate students who obtained their degrees obtained work immediately following their graduation. For example, former graduate student Glen Gronniger entered local industry at the Honeywell Kansas City Plant and Brett Barwick became a postdoctoral researcher at California Institute of Technology with Nobel Laureate Dr. Ahmed Zewail and is now a professor at Trinity College. Roger Bach turned down an interview for a postdoctoral position at Harvard and is running a farm in Kansas, while Maria Becker won a competitive National Research Council postdoctoral fellowship to work at the National Institute of Science and Technology at Boulder Colorado. Our current graduate students Eric Jones, and Peter Beierle are in good standing with our graduate school and are on track to finish their studies in a timely fashion. Most of the undergraduates who participated in our program have entered graduate school. In addition to undergraduate resident at Nebraska, we have provided research opportunities for NSF-funded Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) students from other universities. The PI has organized a summer research program for high school students that brings in about 8 students each year. We are thrilled about the training that we have been able to provide with this funding and the success that our students have had in the job market.
